author: sky.cactus
content: I wonder if it would help with client diversity if the developers implemented new features in other clients first, rather than Geth first?

author: sky.cactus

author: ajsutton
content:
I don't think it's a simple answer here.  On the one hand when people default to prototyping on the majority clients those clients wind up with "free" development and all the other clients have to play catch up. That means the design tends to suit the majority client better and the majority client dev team winds up with more time available for optimisation/other features etc rather than just trying to keep up with specs.

However, when it is the core team doing the prototyping work then that's just them contributing to the ecosystem like all clients do (which works well because we often have different focusses so prototype different stuff and Ethereum as a whole advances faster).

So generally yes it would be helpful if researchers/non-client-developers used minority clients for prototyping more but it also depends on whether the client team has the bandwidth/priorities to give them the assistance they need at that time (plus preferences for languages etc). I'm not sure it makes enough of a difference in final adoption to be worth much advocacy.

author: sky.cactus
content: Excellent insight.  I hadn't considered that, but I agree.

author: protolambda
content: Geth has a reasonably accessible design (i.e. no complex db/sync access patterns, lots of forks, tests and well documented code), and Golang is quite popular too. I don't think we should be surprised it's used for prototyping so often. I like the other clients too, and would like to support them in the testnets, but the story is different there. In general there needs to be some momentum to create more forks/prototypes with other clients to build that non-client-dev expertise in the codebase before large EIPs will start with something else than Geth. And Prysm is there in the list because the team is a relatively active contributor to the EIP / sharding roadmap (which is a good thing, all clients should be encouraged to experiment with new ethereum things), no EIP-4844 author touched it. I would be happy to include any other client that has the bandwidth to bridge the gap between technical outsider and client-dev.
